content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												A very fun FPS/RTS game. Your team commander uses a birds-eye view to issue attack/defend orders and build infrastructure (auto turrets, ammo points, forward spawns, etc) while the rest of the team slays bodies and captures objectives. Theres a very strong team focus, unlike most shooters where everyone just runs around like the wild west. It's even better if you can bring a group of friends and form a squad, and work with your commander to take/defend points (which give your commander more money to spend). The game doesn't have a huge player-base, which is a shame, but there's enough activity to play full matches now and then.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												This game is amazing! It is truely a unique. The RTS aspects of the game is very well done and only takes a few minutes to get the hang of it. The shooting feels very natural and has a very nice class system to it. Playing as the commander (Or RTS mode) is VERY fun even though you are not blowing someone's head off. Without the commander the team is hopeless and can't get basic assets. The commander will build Flame, Machinegun, and rocket sentries to defend the command bunker. They are also in charge of creating health and ammo stations as well as providing all the buildings with power. The goal is for ground units to capture resource collectors to assist in building and expanding the base to help dominate the battlefield. As the round goes on you and your team must destroy the enemy team's command bunker and win the game. The game has four classes which are divided into subclasses based on rank and weaponry. There is Exo (Heavy weapons/Explosives), Assault (Snipers, scouts, infantry), Steath (Spies/Assassins), And Support (Chemical Warfare, Engineers, Medics). This is overall a VERY rich game that is WAY worth the five dollars to buy it. The only thing this game needs are players. The community is still active and we need people to create and populate servers. So grab that Exo suit, and your favorite play style and have a blast!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Yo homies of all shapes and sizes listen up. Dis is my first review and I declare this game is Da BOMB DIGGITY. Not just a bomb, or Da Bomb, but the BOMB DIGGITY! (Put Emphasis on Bomb and DIggity).Seriously though omg, I just got this game on sale and I love it. I came looking for some kind of war-like tower defense, but I found something better. A perfect combination RTS and FPS. I bought it on sale and its the best 3 dollars I ever spent, I would have definetly bought it for full price, or more.  First day I punched in 5 hours. I'm actually surprised by the small community you might find. This game has VERY LITTLE bugs,  and glitches of the sort. Find yourself as a soldier on the ground with variety of assault, exo (heavy), stealth and support. Or, if your confident enough, you can be the commander, which is no easy job! Having to keep track of objectives, planting towers, and guiding your soldiers and assisting them throughout battle. So many ways to strategize your attack, or defense. As an FPS itself aside as a strategy based game, it is amazing as well. It has something much different to offer than any COD or CounterStrike style. It is certainly more strategy that one much pick a class that goes along with the effect on the battlefield. Need to take objectives, Assualt. Need to defend or need for tank, or towers that need to be taken care of, Exo. Is there a tank bothering you, Stealth. Soldiers dying in the field, or towers needing repair, Support, (Medic or Engineer). It isnt the mostly mindless Run and Gun one would find among other FPS. If you are starting to hate that style, this is the game for you. If one could get some friends together to play this game would be amazing too, because when one plays with cooperation, the true potential of this game is unlocked as you struggle through the tough battles ranging fro  m, 30-60 minutes long. All in all, I cant wait to plug in tons of more hours and if you're deciding, you should join me. WOLF OUT DAWG!

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												This game is amazing! It is truely a unique. The RTS aspects of the game is very well done and only takes a few minutes to get the hang of it. The shooting feels very natural and has a very nice class system to it. Playing as the commander (Or RTS mode) is VERY fun even though you are not blowing someone's head off. Without the commander the team is hopeless and can't get basic assets. The commander will build Flame, Machinegun, and rocket sentries to defend the command bunker. They are also in charge of creating health and ammo stations as well as providing all the buildings with power. The goal is for ground units to capture resource collectors to assist in building and expanding the base to help dominate the battlefield. As the round goes on you and your team must destroy the enemy team's command bunker and win the game. The game has four classes which are divided into subclasses based on rank and weaponry. There is Exo (Heavy weapons/Explosives), Assault (Snipers, scouts, infantry), Steath (Spies/Assassins), And Support (Chemical Warfare, Engineers, Medics). This is overall a VERY rich game that is WAY worth the five dollars to buy it. The only thing this game needs are players. The community is still active and we need people to create and populate servers. So grab that Exo suit, and your favorite play style and have a blast!

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I have always been into FPS games and RTS games, and the thought of mixing the two I was a little fickle about, but i have to hand it to the developers, they really put it in a way where i can play this game for hours straight and not get bored. First i should go over the pros of this game, and trust me there are plenty.Now this game treats the RTS and the FPS as two completly corresponding things. You need your Commander (The one player who has the RTS view) and he needs you. As a normal FPS player, you go around accomplishing objectives and killing the enemy team when possible. However if the Commander feels there is something you should all focus on, he may simply issue a comand, and you can see a position in which he wants to defend or attack. The commander also is responsible for building important structures, such as Teleporters, Supply Stations, Armorys and Artilery cannons, and better yet the Artilery cannons have the option for the commander to own them entirley, or for his troops to be able to call in for some support. This adds yet another unique combination of RTS and FPS.A couple of things I found slightly discouraging were the fact that some kits are locked until the commander forks over the resources to reasearch them for your team, and once he does, then you can acess them, but until then you will just have to stare at that Rocket launcer, or grenade launcher until your commander decides he wants you to have it. Another things i find distasteful is the lack of weapon kits, 3 per class(Including the one you need to unlock), yet all of them seem fitting so its not actually too much of a problem. an upside to this is a new player will have the acess to the same weapons as any veteran, which I enjoy, because in many FPS games I have played, veterans usually have an advantage with far better weapons than new players.All in all I would completly recommend Nuclear Dawn to anyone who likes FPS games and RTS games. It beautifully mixs the two and deserves far more fame than it has, I feel if the developers had added more guns and structures this game would be all the rage same as games like Call of Duty and Battlefield, but that is just my opinion, so i will leave it to you to form your own opinion of this game. Have Fun

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												At first I thought this game would be quite complex, but turns out this is one of the easiest FPS games you could find and a really good one at it too.The FPS part has multiple classes who balance themselves very well, Some have high health and are slow heavy weaponed and others have low health but are extremely fast and can cloak themselves to be invisible.You start the game, join a server and there you go. The game has a RTS element meaning there is a player playing the role of  a Commander who gives you orders and sets points to spawn and supply units and all needed support.So if you don't want to run around not knowing what to do, or feel like learning a lot of strategy, this will help you at playing if you follow orders and help others.The RTS part is even better, being a commander you can communicate orders that people might or might not follow. You set up a network of power units, supply units and spawnpoints, those are bought with credits you get by your team capturing points. It's not too complicated but can take some time getting a winning strategy and depends hugely on the players playing.Overall it's surely is one of my favorite games, favorite FPS and is the one I play when I don't want to think too much, just sit back and follow orders and contribute my part to the team.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												SUMMARY: DOUBLE AWESOME BUT DEAD.Once I asked my friend: we got shooters, we got RTS. Why doesn't someone create a game which combines these two genres? Why don't infantry units of RTS can't be alive people who see the game as a shooter? And he answered: there is such a game.And then he sent me this as a gift.First start was very tough. I got to the battefiled unprepared and wasn't able to run more than 2 meters and shot a single bullet without being get killed. Then I left the game and played all the tutorials - learning many things about game goal, controls and abilities of the infantry classes.Second start was much better - I was aware of things happened but still had to learn what teamwork is. First I was running all over the map a a stealh - thinking that I do good just but having fun with backstabbing. Then I had started to enjoy playing assault grenadier. But any choice in a long term wasn't good either for me or my team. Why?... the only thing every ND player should understand is the TEAMWORK. ...it's not just killing more enemies for you team......it's not shooting the same target with other players...It's understanding NEEDS OF YOU TEAM AT THE MOMENT - destroying enemy structures, repairing and protecting building of your team, capturing resources, providing supplies. Everything requires you to master all the classes and react to every situation, changing tactics and following orders of the commander (who sees a game as RTS). You can have favorite classes, you can be very good with them - but when the time comes you should be ready to swich. If you have enemy at you door, sniping hardly will help your team if no one repairs stuff. If enemy bunker is almost down, your assault riffle is useless unless you defend exos from stealths. If you need to capture resources quickly, you would hardly do that with exo unless you have a spawnpoint nearby. Being medic is useless unless there are some players around to be healed. Should I continue? Anyway, after understanding those I fell in love with this game.THE ONLY PROBLEM IT IS DEAD. ACTIVE POPULATION IS HAS DROPPED TO CRITICAL LIMIT. SERVERS ARE FILLED WITH BOTS OR SPECTATING FAKE PLAYERS.GOOD BYE ND, I DID LOVE YOU. R.I.P.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2011
												A hidden gem in the landscape of first person shooters. This hybrid of man-shooting action and real-time strategy may look extremely hardcore and intimidating at first, but beneath it lies a truly wonderful shooter that combines the best of both worlds. If you like your games challenging, then Nuclear Dawn might just be the thing for you. A welcome addition to the genre!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2011
												A deep, team based shooter with a full RTS commander experience. Team play is as important as twitch reflexes in this game and battles range from the slow, steady and methodical war of attrition to the down right hectic and crazy firefights. It just recieved its biggest free content update yet aiming to lower the steep learning curve, and its free to play this weekend! Give it a try then pick it up for cheap ;)

content:
Posted: April 11, 2012
												Not gonna lie to you, right now the game is dying. Which is a shame, because it has a lot of potential and is a good amount of fun even at the moment of writing this. It's a RTS/FPS mixup game and the mixing up works quite well. The game has some issues like matches dragging on forever even though the losing team is pushed back to their base with no chance of coming back or using an XP-System that lets you level up soooo slowly without giving you any real bonus for actually doing so. The main problem is the lack of a playerbase, usually there is one server that is populated and one that is half-populated. If you like iron-sighty multiplayer shooties but you are bored of the same BF/COD all over again, give this unrefined gem a chance.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												I honestly can't believe this is a Source engine based game--it's so polished! I'm really enjoying the concept on this one. Each team elects a single commander who controls all the RTS game elements like placing turrets and other typical support structures. The rest of the team fights FPS style and carries out objectives laid out by the commander with class based characters. It really plays well if you have two teams with expert commanders. A good mix of character skills make this quite a fun experience.This is quite possibly the best integration of Real Time Strategy with First Person Shooting that I have played. Highly recommend.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2011
												The idea of an FPS with an RTS commander isn't necessarily new, and it even seems rather silly in some ways (real people don't blindly run where you tell them, right?) but Nuclear War is an extremely satisfying hybrid. The Commander position is extremely intense and satisfying when you realize the people you're commanding are just that. Realizing that just makes you want to keep them alive.The FPS benefits from the Commander as well. Knowing you're not blindly running around and that someone with a bird's eye view of the battle is leaning you adds a wonderful humanity to the genre. Suddenly you're fighting to make your Commander proud instead of just win. It's great to have someone to trust in the madness.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												Really interesting game, a satisfying mix between the FPS and RTS genres. It's based on the HL2 mod "Empires", which in my opinion is better gameplay-wise, but this one sure is graphically superior (and more polished). If you like multiplayer games based on teamwork as a soldier and leading your faction to victory through careful planning as a commander, this one's for you.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2011
												Nuclear Dawn is basically a rip-off of Command & Conquer - Renegade and Battlezone II: Combat Commder built on the Source engine but without AI and vehicles (from what I have seen thus far).It looks awesome though and the city designs are simply amasing, but like if they won't add any vehicle or some spawnable AI like in the forementioned, I doubt I will play this much.The game is currently in Beta testing fase, so there will be changes, but from what I understand the developers have limited the so called RTS experience to the building of structures (turrets, research, power stations, that kinda stuff).And Steam, seriously, don't say RTS - FPS is a new concept in gaming, it seriously isn't. Most companies just didn't burn want to burn their hands on it, so there are only 2 others (as far as I know), 1 of which I think is older than Half Life...yeah...not Half Life 2, Counterstrike, or any other form, the absolute 1st Half Life...Worth a try though, when its on discount...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game has demonstated that commited players can ensure a thriving community. Five years since it's release and most days people flood to RedStone(A Popular Server); Most days the server has players(though some days can be quite).This Mod has been well refined, though not all bugs have been ironed out. However, none of the bugs are severe enough to have an inpact on your expience when playing Nuclear Dawn.Battles are immense; with typically 30 players fighting side by side against the opposing team. The gameplay is dynamic, and a well thought out team based stategy is key to playing this game well.You can never really determine how a game will pan out, as just when you're at the peak of victory, the enermy team gets a foothold and the table turns against you as your enermy formulise a new strategy.

												+Easy to learn+Base building and resource management+Variety of weapons and kits for each class+Good map map design-Tutorial is bugged for some people (myself included) however it has not hampered my ability to playServers are relatively empty depending on time of day, so pick this up on a sale (goes as low as $2 USD).Game feels solid and balanced, a level 3 (like I was) can just as easily kill a level 80 (like I did :D ). It actually feels kind of cool being able to ask the commander for a resupply, or to set up an anti-stealth radar, etc. and then watch him drop it down a minute or so later. Gameplay is rewarding and definitely worth purchasing :3

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												I bought this game with high expectations. Some may judge me for this. However, with the amount of advertising that once flooded the internet for this game, I thought that the extra advertising effort displayed how much work was put into the game.I am a huge fan of both RTS and FPS games. I had even dreamed of designing a hybrid one day. Then this game came along and offered both. Of course I had to buy it... only to be disappointed. The first of the problems was in choosing the engine; the Source engine is dated and ugly. Things that had potential to look awesome simply didn't. The menu and interface is ugly. The textures are blurry and the lighting is lousy. Not a pretty game. But many agree that graphics are not the most important aspect. Okay, granted. Let's throw graphics completey out. How does the game play? There are lots of tactical decisions made, and I appreciated how the game was less "Go out and kill people" and more "Follow the orders of the person who can see what's happening". But what if the person who was elected commander is actually an idiot? Well... too bad. You are definitely going to lose. Playing as soldiers isn't much better; the assasin's blade is supposed to be able to back-stab in one hit, similar to the Spy in Team Fortress 2. A slight miss means betraying your position and unsuccesfully killing the enemy, even if the hit still hits the guy in the back: this glitch irritated me no end.But people will always be idiots in public matches. So you want to play alone. How does that do? In a word: terrible. Even worse, in fact. When in commander mode (since AI refuses to be a commander for either team) you face an unmotivated enemy that does not desire to expand their base and spams non-stop uncoordinated attacks at you. If you took the helm as a commander, giving orders only pains you as you watch your teammate's miserable pathfinding get them all stuck before they reach your designated target. After a long, gruelling match you may wind up in victory after expanding your base all the way to the door of the enemy's base. But it won't be FUN. Isn't that what's important? After finally destroying the pitiful structures the enemy thinks is a base, you will sit back and ask, "Did I actually enjoy any of that??"The game shows potential, but unfortunately not much else. If you managed to find 9 other buddies to do a LAN party, then maybe it might be kinda enjoyable. But at its current price range, it is not worth the buy. Maybe if it went free2play with cosmetic upgrades, or maybe sank sub-$5 range, it would be more worth your time.4/10. Avoid.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I'm sorry, I just can't recommend the game. There's a great deal of glaring problems that haven't been fixed since the 2011 release date.The 'Human turret' feature of the exo is bad. A very limited FOM and quick turning speed. It should be 180 degrees turning but with a speed reduction.The EXO is overpowered. You can destroy people at close range and long range with ease.Choice of weapons is extremely limited, By which I mean you get about less than 20 in the whole game.Stealth is just a silly class. You can uncloak instantly and then shoot somebody or stab them, Then go invisible again. It doesn't even OHK on a backstab.The length of the cloak on the stealth is too long.Assault shouldn't have constant thermal vision. Have it so that you flick it on sometimes just to give the place a check over.Weapons take FAR too long to kill. I have 30 bullets in my MP7 but I can't kill one person with that? Give me some slack.Give us health regen. Like 1 health a second or maybe 1 health per 2 seconds. It's so rare to find a medic or a supply station.Iron sights on all the guns are disgusting. I'd like to track my enemy's head without them hiding behind my own damn gun.Engineers should be able to construct buildings. Commanders don't often put them in tactical positions.Grenades are clunky. You throw them too quickly and they hardly kill.These are just the problems I spotted in my first hour of gameplay. All in all, I just don't see myself playing much of this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												If you'd like to hear my full thoughts on Nuclear Dawn, you can listen to the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[soundcloud.com]Nuclear Dawn pits two teams against each other as they vie for control points and try to push their offensive into the other team's base. One player on each team takes the role of the commander and views the battlefield from an overhead view, effectively playing the game as an RTS. The commander groups players into squads, issues orders, constructs buildings, and lends battlefield assistance. Meanwhile other players can choose between four classes: assault, exo (i.e. heavy), support, and stealth. Within each class there are also different loadouts available.What makes Nuclear Dawn great is that it really does play well as both a shooter and a strategy game. No team can succeed without both the commander and the other players doing a good job and working together. I was surprised by how much being a commander actually felt like playing an RTS.On the negative side of things, the whole aesthetic of the game is fairly generic and uninteresting. It's basically all just slightly futuristic war-torn gray/brown cities and cookie cutter soldiers without that well-defined of a setting. I found that it made it a bit difficult to learn the map layouts since everything just looked so similar.Also problematic is that building very often get in the way of the commander's view and I wish that they would have been made transparent for the commander. It often means that you have to do a fair bit of manipulating the camera to see the action.Overall, Nuclear Dawn is a great competitive online experience. While the game is a bit old, I could still always find at least one server with a fair number of players, so it's still worth getting for that. If you want a game to play online that takes some time to get into and does something a little more interesting than your typical team deathmatch, I can definitely recommend Nuclear Dawn.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Being short and brief, this is a multiplayer focused game ! but ! there is no player base! It's like a car with no gas at the moment so even if you think that getting it for two or three dollar's is a bargain then go ahead, prove your doubts.(I know, I did)Finally I'll say dev's did a good job, no 'monie stealez', 'big bad bugz'(the tutorial was a big messed up but I survived), just a simple game on the platter. Sadly it's feels more extinct than a dodo right now.And from here on the TL:DR section or my 'rant' starts.I was lucky enough to have access to battle zone II, if you know the game then it saves me the trouble of explaining how 'similar' or 'different' it was to Nuclear Dawn  but if not. It was and still is very 'similar' but 'different' to Nuclear Dawn. Google the game if you're interested.Amazing concept plus theory combined with a fluid-ish game mechanics make's this one hell of a decent competetor on steam for a low hardware spec game. The only problem is that the mechanics of the commander/RTS are overshadowed by the Shooter/fps. Now all this jargon is for the time when the game has a player base.At the moment of writing this review, umm... give or take two minute's. I literally counted 7 player's including me, the 6 on a new york server and I starring in horror, remembering the previous reviews about the game.An honest message to the devs/owner's. This IP of your's is near death, I payed, played and finally I'm praying that I can get my measely two dollars refunded. It might seem like a really penny pinching move and honestly I won't argue. It is one, though I stand by my thoughts that this game is at the moment broken. Not by design, code or bugs but by ergonomic means.All work and no praise make's dev really grinchy, especially the one's who turned this idea into a reality. A really good idea for the record so kudos for that.I'll end this rant on the note that by no means after getting through the tutorial I felt the urge to rip open the ethernet cable to open the 'Internetz' rift and finding the devs and tickle torture them. I honestly feel sad that this game is in such a remorseful state.I'd buy this game on it's full price if it was still 'alive'. Oh, for reading till here I have an advice for devs. Make the game f2p.I know I know, just a penny pinching move by a broke♥♥♥♥♥guy but I'd say it's words of a 'wise' broke♥♥♥♥♥guy telling you to throw a Final Hail Mary.Revive the player base and to make money introduce DLC with different game mode's. Hell charge player's to be able to play as the commander. Introduce skins to make profits or recoup the losses. The game is there, it's either that or just shelve this IP and move on if it's not worth the while.That's all folks-fin

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Nuclear Dawn is at the end of its life. Even though there are many servers that are running, only one of them seems to be active with human players at any time. The problem with that server is that it's located in Europe, and the ping is around 200 or higher for me. The maps and environments look great. The futuristic science fiction aesthetic works really well with the weapons and special abilities. Each of the four classes offer a varied and atypical approach to combat. The unlocks also seem to help you through the battles, even though it takes a while to get them through the experience system. In addition, there are many weapon kit loadouts available to all classes; making gameplay very different through the combination of classes, loadouts, and unlocks. Resource capturing can be extremely fun while trying to dodge bullets from enemy fire, and if you have a good commander, you will be in an excellent position to push forward against the enemy's main base. Speaking of the commander feature, this can also make or break your enjoyment of Nuclear Dawn. Commanders require experience and know-how of the game. From extensive knowledge of map locations, to the much needed in-depth tactical familiarity required at different times throughout the match, and the placement of necessary strategic structures around the map. Even though the game allows for players to start a mutiny vote against the commander, finding a good player to fill that role can sometimes be problematic. The commander must also be caring, as she or he should not approach the job as a one person show. This commander mechanic is very similar to the one found in Natural Selection 2. While all of these features sound as though they meld together an amazing, thoroughly enjoyable gaming experience, the sad fact that the multiplayer community is basically dead defeats all chances of greatness and playability. Unless you are specifically in Europe, Nuclear Dawn simply cannot be enjoyed to its full potential. Its solitary European populated server whose ping is well in the 200s makes this game completely unplayable for me. Even if you are in Europe, there will be many times that you will join the one server, and it will only have three or four people playing. This is a multiplayer online only game without a community. Maybe the upcoming update that will supposedly also add native Linux support will help.Nuclear Dawn is okay.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Nuclear Dawn is, as it's name tells, a game at the dawn of a nuclear war. If it, mostly an FPS but there are a few different ways to play the game :1- You're a simple soldier, on the field. Like in most of the other FPSs, you target an enemy and shoot him down (or he does it). You can choose to have either a shotgun, a sniper or an assault rifle and can detect enemy camos.2- You're an assassin, on the field. You can make yourself invisible (become a camo) and stab your enemies from behind OR you just shoot them down with a sniper OR you use some bombs, kinda C4s ('cause you can activate them from a long distance).3- You are a BADASS tank with either a BADASS machine-gun or a SUPER BADASS rocket launcher. And like most of the heavy tanks' infantry, you're slow as ****.4- You are THE man of the game. You're the commander. You build stuff, as if you were a player of some of the tower defense games but, also, you choose either to upgrade your team, help them while on the field or just go with them.Just seeing this, you (should) guess it's not an FPS like all the others. This one is a mix between Call Of Duty and tower defense's games such as World Of Empire or Plant VS Zombies while being much better.Now, let's check out the good and bad things of this game...GOOD- multiplayer and solo player available,- not bad graphics,- an easy controllable shooter, even with a keyboard,- a simple but helpful tutorial (to learn of to really play, even though I never even dated to finish it),- no stupid players, just a few games entirely made of bots,- the online games are never (well, since I started playing) full.BAD- some online games can be so long and, sometimes, start to get you bored,- some commanders can't make your team win and the online servers don't have so much players,- you need to know how to really play an FPS.So, yeah. You really need to learn how to play on FPSs ;)

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												This game is a lot of fun. That being said, it needs a lot of work. First and most important is gamepad support. I'm using the Logitec F710 Gamepad. If you're not familiar, it's the gamepad you see in the Controller Support badges on some game's store page. There's no way to operate as commander (rts mode), switch weapons, or select commands for your team with my gamepad. Operating the menu is nearly impossible and you cannot play through the tutorials without using your keyboard. Very annoying. Server selection is moderate at best. Normally there are 2 or 3 servers which have 20-32 players, 2 or 3 with under 10, and the rest are empty. I'm currently running Ubuntu 14.04. The following problem may be isolated to Linux, but it's worth mentioning. After I play 2-3 matches this game freaks out. It starts lagging in the menu (and in game) so bad that I have to close the application from the desktop. The 'quit' button doesn't even work. I'm glad I got this game for $2, otherwise I would feel ripped off.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												It's not a bad idea, just a poorly executed one. Basically, you won't notice the difference between a normal fps and this hybrid. If the game had a competitive scene, it would be a lot better, but sadly it doesn't. The Commander simply doesn't have enough influence on the game.As the commander you are mostly doing a monotonous job: place turrets everywhere. It's a lot of busywork. If the simple soldier thinks the commander's idea is good, he does what the commander tells him. If not, he won't. So at the end of the day it all comes down to how good you are at fps games in general, because everyone on your team is an idiot either way.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												So far, I can only rate this game based on the infantry training section. I'll revise later if I'm somehow to blame for the lack of information provided.Now, in training, the assault class is straightforward enough to not be a problem. Point and shoot, use goggles for seeing stealth. Straight to the point, no questions, no confusion.Exo training is where things started getting vague. I'm told that I'm heavy, with a lack of mobility, and am told to use the minigun to eliminate some targets, followed by the class special with lockdown. Right after this, I'm told about a siege weapon, and told to destroy the target using an M95. BUT the problem is that there's NO EXPLANATION about which button to press to get to the M95, or whether I need to change kits, or how to change kits. Nothing is given whatsoever, so I was left to using the chaingun to destroy the remaining structures. I'm not sure if I'm missing it in the interface somewhere or whether there's no option to customize as a level 0, but either way, it's literally impossible that I should or could know this information. They need to specify what the hell I need to do and what button or section does it.Stealth again was straightforward as far as the training, but I can speak as to the difficulty of the class regarding any of the kits since they don't train you with anything but the generic first kit. Which is also frustrating, since I would like to test out each of the sub classes. THAT'S WHAT TRAINING IS SUPPOSED TO BE FOR.Lastly, support training, which seems like it should be pretty easy to learn, if it weren't for not being able to find how to change kits. I'm told to drop a health kit, then to destroy an enemy supply station with my torch, followed by repairing a friendly one. The problem is that I'm put into the medic kit, then not told how to change to the engineer kit. Effectively making my tutorial an impossible cockblock that can't be bypassed.So, in summary, more explanation is needed in the training, as well as a more in depth tutorial on kits and at least basics of how to switch between them. Especially in the training sections, where we're learning how to play the damn game for the first time.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Very cool concept of hybrid multiplayer RTS-FPS, but it becomes very dependent on your team and commander. It is FRUSTRATING taking out enemy infantry in waves, only to have to enemy building materialize around you, and you realize your inability to do anything to take them out.  It only ends with you being spawn trapped as it rains down turrets of machineguns, rockets and flamethrowers as you realize there is a mad god out there that hates you. The Starcraft Brood War Opening Cinematic honestly describes it perfectly, your the marine though : 


YouTube™ Video: Starcraft: Brood War Opening 

			Views: 793,009		

			StarCraft : Brood War is a real-time strategy game in which players control any of three different species battling for domination.		

 An AI commander might be pretty interesting and the addition of vehicles could be really neat, but at the moment there isn't a worthwhile community or reason to play this regularly. It is fun so it's a shame that it isn't going on as strong, but I think the core gameplay concepts are worth further development.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												First let me clear,This is an online-only game. I didn't realize that when I bought thinking it would be a fun RTS to mess around with. You can play bot matches but it's mainly only for online.I've owned this game for a while but was put off by it. I felt that I should give it a solid chance and so I played the tutorial and a couple games before writing this. Nuclear Dawn has a cool idea. I loved that you had a nice blend of RTS and as well as some FPS qualities. Unfortunately you can tell everything is messy and just plain hard to see from the get go. I was playing on high settings as well. I've seen N64 games more visually appealing than this. There's no story or memorable soundtrack, people don't even bother joining squads. When I tried to apply to be a commander. First it told me that I couldn't, I assumed because we had one already. Turns out we didn't, so I tried applying. It told me to spawn first as I'm running around trying my best to snipe and clearly already spawned and so my entire team ran without a commander and lost miserably.This game was just a disgusting experience and If I could, I would demand my 5 dollars be refunded.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												UPDATE: I just wanted to say to the people who have down voted my review, can you honestly tell me you prefer Source over Unreal or idTech?  Can you name a single thing that Source does better than other engines?  I ask because the only reason I can see to down vote my review is my stance on Source (which has such a cult following it'd make Taylor Swift jealous - and it's equally lackluster compared to its competition).  Nothing else I said here is really debatable.  The tutorial IS broken, the achievement IS unobtainable, and the crouch/sniper issues remain.  Even if this was done in Unreal it'd still get a negative review from me.  Of course, then I doubt these issues would happen in the first place.  Anyhow, onward to my review for anyone who still cares to read it...This is yet another game held back by the Source Engine.  Yes, you read that right.  I said it.The truth is that the Source Engine - much beloved by (nearly) all - is an outdated relic that gained a sterling reputation in 2004 as a good engine - and then nobody ever through to question that again.  Meanwhile, Unreal Enginer 3 (or really even UE2), idTech 4/5, or something like Unity are now far superior in every measurable way to Source Engine.If this game has been on Unreal Engine 2 (or better yet, 3) I wouldn't be uninstalling it right now.  But yeah, the engine ruins the game here.  If anyone wants specific notations, here ya go:The FPS/RTS hybrid model works brilliantly in this game.  I have played actual RTS games that weren't this good even on the RTS side, the the FPS is your standard near-future military shooter.However, this is where source starts to rear its ugly head.  Unlike every other FPS engine in existance, you cannot stop walking mid-step.  This makes for awkward movement that feels like you're controlling a 9 legged elephant rather than a human, and makes taking any semblence of aim while your character is moving impossible.  This movement is just like TF2, another Source Engine title, and I can't stand it there either.The sniper rifles lack variable zoom.  While not terribly uncommon for sniper rifles in modern FPS games to lack variable zoom, this is still a mark against it, and once again this is made worse by the use of Source Engine.  Whereas other games might allow you to crouch and stay there, Source forces you to constantly hold the crouch key to remain crouched.  And unlike other engines where this is the case, the game lacks even an option to make crouch a toggle.  This means you're stuck quickscoping everything, or else not playing a sniper, because the standard Assault Rifle is accurate, when hip-fired, to almost the same range as your sniper rifle is zoomed.  Since you can't really crouch and you have the lowest health, you are left 100% dependant on your cloak just to survive at all with the stealth kit - and it takes 3x as long to recharge as it does to discharge.  Which would be fine, if you could more easily crouch behind cover...which you can't, because Source.The tutorial is broken.  While the RTS tutorial works fine, there are two points in the FPS tutorial where the game is supposed to forcibly change your loadout for you...and it doesn't.  The first time you are playing the "heavy" class and it's supposed to change your chaingun for a rocket launcher, but you can reload about a dozen times and still complete that section with the chaingun.  The last tutorial, for the support class, is supposed to equip a repair torch.  Unlike the other bug, there is no way around this and so players who try to get every achievement need to take note - THE ACHIEVEMENT FOR COMPLETING THE SECOND TUTORIAL IS UNOBTAINABLE.  Frankly, once again, I'm blaming this on Source, though in this case I am not 100% sure it's an engine-related issue.All in all, great concept, and very good execution DESPITE the source engine.  I'm still not gonna play it any more though, because the problems and quirks of Source bug me too much to enjoy the game itself.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Nuclear Dawn is similar to Natural Selection 2. They both offer a fight mode and a commander mode. Unlike natural selection 2, both of the teams are human and use guns. The game was fun, but it was a fairly unremarkable FPS. Other than the commander mode, I can't think of much that sets it apart from many other modern shooters. I don't think I'd recommend picking it up unless you can get it real cheap. Possibly in a bundle. There are just other shooters that do it better for the same price.I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2012
												This game has depth, but it only leaves me hungry for Natural Selection 2.Definitely learn to command in this game. It's where the fun is truly at and will help you understand what you need to do as a typical soldier on the ground.The game is still glitchy at times, with show-stopping bugs that can keep an entire team from getting access to "advanced kits", which is kind of a keystone to making sure an entire group of game-players can have a ghost of a chance at putting up a fight against their opponents.I think the EXO is overpowered in pub play, making their minigun a veritable sniper rifle in spite of the presence of cloakers who can 1 shot backstab anything. This isn't a bad game, it's just a game that quite honestly is slowly pacing its ideas and came out years after its countdown website hype to launch with something rather generic.

												It tries to take the Natural Selection formula and apply it to modern combat, but it fails. It's just not that fun. The commander doesn't get much to do, the maps are either too big to accurately command or too small to build in, some of the classes are useless, and it lacks innovation. Multiplayer is pretty much dead as well. Save your money for Natural Selection II, a game that takes the RTS/FPS concept and does it in a more unique, intresting, and well executed way.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I played this during a free weekend a long while back. Unfortunately the claim that it doesn't cripple or dilute either side of the FPS/RTS gameplay is quite wrong as far as the RTS side goes. As an RTS fan I can tell you that being the commander in this game is not at all like playing an RTS. Construction of buidlings is slow and limited, orders are pretty much just always ignored, and its rare that you actually get to do something useful. Very boring. I wonder when developers of FPS/RTS hybrids are going to realize that in an RTS you need to have units to control, not just a bunch of human players who will run around doing whatever they want and ignore you?My larger gripe as far as the game overall goes is that it takes a very long time to complete a match, yet the outcome is almost always clear within the first few minutes. You always know who's going to win in spite of a few minor pushes back and forth and virtually the entire match is just a matter of the obvious losers doing everything in their power to delay the inevitable. Very frustrating and boring regardless of which side you're on.

number of helpful: 11 of 29 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												This game has potential, but not enough to warrant a pricetag.At most, there's only ever 1 server with a substantial number of players on it, probably due to the fact that this game is 3 years old and still costs money. It's okay. The mix of real-time-strategy and first-person-shooter is a combination that I did not expect would work, but it blends reasonably well. The combat mechanics are okay, the weapons customization is okay, the class system is okay, and it's pretty cool to see your efforts on the ground visibly pay of as your commander builds things around you.I rate this game as "okay", though I think more people would play it if it were free to play.

number of helpful: 17 of 42 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Nuclear Dawn is the first game to offer a full FPS and RTS experience, within a single gameplay model, without crippling or diluting either side of the game. As a soldier, explore war-torn post-apocalyptic landscapes, modelled on modern cities, and take the fight to your enemies as armoured, assault or stealth infantry, using various weapons across ten distinct load-outs to accomplish your objectives. The first person shooter action in Nuclear Dawn is hard, fast and unforgiving, with weapons that rely on skill and tactics more than on twitch reflexes and map memorization. Then, take Nuclear Dawn above the action, and play as the commander. Organize your fellow players in squads, and assign them to tactical objectives. Plan the resource routes for your army, and production of your structures for forward deployment. Exploit the terrain and resource point locations to block your enemies’ advance, and crush their plans in an iron fist. Research and implement new technologies to give your soldiers the edge on the battlefield, and set up forward bases to lead the assault on your enemies, with a full complement of defensive and offensive structures to choose from, to build your perfect fortress.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Biggest Crap i ever played in my life.I bought it for 1.99Euros and it's not worth it. I would buy myself rather some sweets instead this game.The Soldiers are useless in this game. If someone puts 3-4 turrets it's over. You can sit and wait. Unless it's fun for you to shot at one turret 10-15min.The game feels cheap, i mean really cheap. It feels like not finished at all. There is no leave button when you press "ESC", you can't set "Hold to ADS". I thought Call of Duty was bad. But this game is basicly comander vs comander. Soldiers make totaly no sense in this game. Bots are locking on your face and you can jump try to dodge but they still hit all bullets. So movement makes no sense.If the turrets had some "limited" turn around speed so you could somehow dodge them or not instant shooting just something like 1s to track on you. Would be nice.They would need to take a group of players that actualy play alot of games and make a plan for this game. The IDEA is amazing. Maps look worse than from a Browser Game. The Menu ingame is crap, you can't switch classes ingame. If yes, i don't know how. There is no "tutorial" how to play a game like this. You can't add anything special to this game.I tested the ADS (Aiming) on this game, i aimed at the wall and start shooting. NO bullet #NO! bullet hit that point where i was aiming. All bullets flew 1-5cm next to the place where i was aiming at. So yeah.That game needs some serious "upgrade".

												I got the game as a gift in the Steam Christmas Sale 2011 and played it for the first time about half a year later, because I really didn't know what I would get.Nuclear Dawn combines the elements of a squad-based shooter like Battlefield with the elements of an RTS: One player of each team becomes the commander, who can build defensive and offensive structures like turrets or power stations, while his teammates have to control ressource points and exterminate the opposing team.The mechanis work great if you are lucky to be in a good team - if not, you're doomed.The balancing on each map is outstanding and the leveling system with new perks is rewarding, but you have to put a lot of effort in it before it pays off; maybe a bit too much regarding the small rewards.But it's fun for a quick battle and the graphics look good, too.

												Excellent.If you like RTS you'll enjoy sitting in the commander's chair and having your soldiers be your eyes and ears. If you like shooters, you'll love the lfd2 engine fps-action you get as you go around securing resources for your commander and killing anyone who dares tread in your team's territory.That said, it's a team game and so -- to better serve your commander and team -- you should join a squad and team up with some folks to accomplish particular objectives. The game doesn't enforce joining a squad which has been the only negative I've seen (other than getting stuck with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ commander; which isn't too big of a problem since you can demote him and get him replaced with relative ease).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2011
												I picked up this FPS on sale on another site, and it is really is a good time. The game is a FPS with persistant player stats, deployable structes, c&h objectives, seige objectives, a class system, and an array of perks and weapons. And it is a package done on the whole in a very unique manner. On each side one person will enter a command both, and play the game as a RTS overlay, while the rest of the team plays as a fps. The comander will deploy structures, can issue orders (which generate xp for the ground troops when followed), research tech, and so on. A lot of a good round depends on having a good comander... thankfully, there are voting tools that let a team have control over who is running the show. The FPS action can be fast and intense, and is often a good time. The only real weakness of the game is the fairly small player pool at this time. Not to worry, there are games going on all the time, but it would be nice to see more severs with player numbers posted.

												This game is a hidden gem. It's probably one of the best strategy-shooters on the market. Playing as either the commander or a soldier feeds a strong sense of urgency and duty, and an adrenaline rush either way. There's nothing like trying to coordinate between com orders and where your dense allies are going. Seriously, it's a great game. Opening up achievements and perks over time that actually let you define your play (scope, silencer, specialized ammo, etc.) really gives you a sense of contributing. Mad props to people who play the /much needed/ medic or engineer.Favorite part: swearing at a commander who refuses to put down any supply stations. 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												With a unique HUD system and very interesting twist of adding RTS elements to the FPS genre, Nuclear Dawn is quite the showpiece! There is also a nicely done rank-up system that allows you to gain spending tokens to use on upgrades and abilities, similar to Borderlands or Diablo. And it's got quite a few things to unlock, so it'll keep you busy for awhile.HOWEVERI do feel like the leveling-up system is a two-edged sword as I have come across players who are so far in that they survived a direct headshot from the sniper rifle. Barely, but they did nonetheless. So be ready for anything to happen once you pull the trigger. The game seems to play very fast paced, frantic, and is a heckuva lotta fun! But it lacks once really critical aspect that makes any online experience a good one:PLAYERS.....

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2012
												A year after release, and a near-dear community doesn't stop this ball from rolling. Nuclear Dawn is an FPS/RTS hybrid, akin to Natural Selection. The gameplay feels like Battlefield 2142 mixed with Command & Conquer. This is a game that is worth the cash, and unlike BF games, there's a lesser learning curve, as simple as playing the tutorials gets you the foundation of how to play this genius game. Running on the Source engine, it's also a spectacle. When you aren't looking at the brown that has preluded and infiltrated this game, you see some vivid graphics, curtousy of Interwave's incredible map designers. There's a way for everyone to play, and all you need to do is try it.This game may be empty, but Interwave is dedicated, and they plan a BIG patch for their anniversary. I recommend you buy it and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This is on of the best Multi-player FPS that (almost) no one plays. Only one working server that I found - too bad !This is a different FPS for the best - you need to gain control on a map, gather resources and kill the opposition. Each squad has a commander that uses the gathered resources to build facitilies as spawn points, recharge (ammo+health) etc. , and he has a totally different role - he sees the map overhead and guides the troopres across to defend bases and to attack enemy targets, which are tottaly destructible (as on your side). Therefore, it is best to play it, with earphones+mic.The game has the standards 4 classes, but it has a unique twist - you gain abilities in between games and different one within the game itself (better class weapons, better health, better ammo).The graphics are good and the sound is good too, what makes you wanna ask:How come it's a total miss by the gaming community ???

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2011
												One of the most unique games I've every played. Combines Real Time Strategy gameplay where you get to be the commander of an entire faction, to First-Person-Shooter where you work with your squad to take enemy troops and structures out.What's awesome is the numerous ways you can play and win the battle, from 4 distinct classes of soldiers to unique weponry and structures of each faction.Graphics is good, and uses Source Engine. The sound effects get repetitive, and there are a few balance issues where a few classes tend to get overpowered once they get their tier2 weapons researched. However, I've just played closed Beta and the actual game may differ. There's an in-game voice chat and support for any 3rd party voice provider too. It's awesome when you get your friends together and get 16 vs 16 battles going!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2011
												A very intense multiplayer experience. The game is currently in its "Vanilla" version and there is still some balancing/tweaking/polishing to be done. That doesn't mean, however, that this isn't a quality product. Far from it. First of all, it feels very "unique". I haven't played any other FPS/RTS hybrid in the past, i have tried however most multiplayer shooters that have come out in the last 4-5 years and this one feels much more intense. Even if you prefer a lone-wolf approach in multiplayer games this game will make you want to get involved with the team to hold out that capture point for 30s longer, to siege that turret and EMP their spawns, leaving you with an adrenaline rush and a great sense of satisfaction, knowing that you won that battle fighting tooth and nail against the opponent. Dev support is also a big plus for this one. All in all a VERY recommended purchase.

												WOW!  This is a LOT of fun!  I didn't expect it to be so awesome.  It plays a lot like that Half-Life mod "Natural Selection" - except the teams are balanced much more evenly.  It's all about how good your commander and players work together.  Assault is good at spotting Stealth.  Stealth is good at assassinating Exos.  Exos are good at killing Assault.  And then you have Engineers/Medics which play support roles, excellent at destroying/repairing structures, and keeping groups of players alive.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												If you happen to have played Savage or Natural Selection, you'll feel right at home. The graphics are suprisingly good for a 2011 game - I was stunned by some of the interiors. There are some flaws though. The guns feel weird (in a bad way) and movement is floaty. The inclusion of ironsights irks me to no end. In terms of size the community is completely dead by my standards (2 servers at the best of times), although at least what remains is friendly. The amount of commander buildings/research is roughly on par with Natural Selection 1 - whch has always been too little IMO. The potental for massive turnarounds is quite low past the first 5-10 minutes, which often leads to drawn out, rather pointless games. With all that said, I am able to still recommend the game, but mostly to people who are already fans of the genre (FPS-RTS hybrid).

This game will take some good time to get used to, recommended for advanced players, A really good expeirence with some good ideas, and awesome style.UPDATE: Now that Ive gotten to level 70, it opens up way more at this point. The perks come with lots and lots of playtime. But for some reason, it is always fun! Theres always a counter to an opponents strategy. Playing smart has never been more vital in a a game. On top of that, The level design is just top notch. My absolute favorite shooter.

												A great combo of RTS and FPS, great community and a fun game which can add up to some massively cool battles. Maps are fairly large so there's quite a lot of variety, along with workshop support but I haven't played many community maps.Pros+Unique RTS, FPS combo+Can have pretty big and cool battles+Classes are fairly balanced, I haven't had a problem where one class surpasses the rest+Source engine is fab+Teamworky stuff+Community is nice+Normally decent commanders+I can imagine this game would be incredible with a bunch of palsCons-Very few used servers-Guns feel a little bit weak-Fairly dependent on having a decent commander, but this has never been much of an issue to me+-Games can be very long; can be seen as pro or con depending on the amount of time you haveA solid 8 flaming dinguses out of 10 from me,A must buy if you're looking for a bit of a change.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2011
												[Re-edit]:[TL;DR: Nuclear Dawn is fun but lacks frequent playerbase to keep it fun and AI is backwards.]Nuclear Dawn is certainly a well paced shooter with the means of having a RTS side if that was more of your thing. It's not the prettiest graphics wise as it does show a certain amount of age but I do like what it was attempting. The FPS side of things are fairly simple to understand and RTS side, it's not too hard to understand. But now onto the problems that I found with the game.First of all, the AI. It was a few patches ago that they introduced the AI System and while it mean you can play by yourself, the game originally was designed for Player vs Player interactions. And as such, the AI opponent will never build any buildings and will just simply run endlessly at your base, guns blazing and probably would only win if you decide to quit. Your AI teammates are just as thick and one time while I was stuck in my command chair, I ordered my underlings to capture a crucial point that was 5 feet away from the spawner. They gave me the affirmmative and I waited until they moved into the point. Now it takes three to capture this crucial location and there were five of them that had used the spawner. Only one of the bots made it into the capture range. The rest stopped against a knee high fence and stared at their lonely comrade with maybe a longing glance. And nothing I did afterwards could make them move and the enemy AI was pressumably doing the same thing somewhere else as they were notably absent.The maps are fun enough, albeit a bit small feeling if you're a seasoned RTS player. FPS wise, the indoor areas are great for firefights but when it comes to fighting outside, things can be a bit one sided if the enemy commander can just hail nukes on you and insta-kill you from the get-go. It's a good game, don't take things the wrong way, but the AI do need some improvements. At least they don't complain that you're hacking when you headshot dominate them the whole game. [Original: One of the most awesomest FPS on Steam. Great deal of fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												A great game for multiplayer with a nice twist with the commanding. You can be a soldier (one out of 11 classes)  and if you want, you can apply to command the team in that game. The soldiers fight on the battlefield like a normal team deathmatch + capture points. But the real twist is the commander, who builds turrets, spawn points, supply stashes, researches more advanced bulidlings and improvements for the team, and watched the battle in a strategy-like view from above. It's pretty awesome to communicate over ingame voice chat with your commander (or your team, depending if you are the commander), who then builds a turret nearby to help you out of a tricky situation, activates the artillery to provide covering fire, or builds a barrier wall to allow you to shoot from cover. This game is really fun and I would love more people to buy it so there are more active servers to play on,  which is the only downside, only several servers are populated at a time. All in all it is a great game and deffinetly worth your money. With the new steam refund system there is nothing preventing you from giving it a go for a day or two and see if you like it. Hope to see you soon!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I traded for this game a few years ago in TF2... I played less than a hour or so before.. Hated it. Now in 2015; with only a fraction of players left online -- I discovered it's actually pretty good; you just gotta give it time. Where to start.. Each class is balanced, the maps are creative and fun to play (plenty of routes to flank your enemies) and it's got a unique feature where each team can have a commander who'll create buildings to help your team move closer to the enemy base.. Really creative; this game needs more exposure! Only thing that might be unbalanced when you first start is the perk system.. Basically with every few levels you unlock perks; some of these can be VERY powerfull (e.g. suppressor) if used correctly and new players may be a bit discouraged until they get their levels up. The closest thing I can compare it to? A mix between MW2+C&C Renegade.. I recommend it :) Looking forward to playing alongside/against you!

												WOW!  This is a LOT of fun!  I didn't expect it to be so awesome.  It plays a lot like that Half-Life mod "Natural Selection" - except the teams are balanced much more evenly.  It's all about how good your commander and players work together.  Assault is good at spotting Stealth.  Stealth is good at assassinating Exos.  Exos are good at killing Assault.  And then you have Engineers/Medics which play support roles, excellent at destroying/repairing structures, and keeping groups of players alive.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												If you happen to have played Savage or Natural Selection, you'll feel right at home. The graphics are suprisingly good for a 2011 game - I was stunned by some of the interiors. There are some flaws though. The guns feel weird (in a bad way) and movement is floaty. The inclusion of ironsights irks me to no end. In terms of size the community is completely dead by my standards (2 servers at the best of times), although at least what remains is friendly. The amount of commander buildings/research is roughly on par with Natural Selection 1 - whch has always been too little IMO. The potental for massive turnarounds is quite low past the first 5-10 minutes, which often leads to drawn out, rather pointless games. With all that said, I am able to still recommend the game, but mostly to people who are already fans of the genre (FPS-RTS hybrid).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Come Back to this Really Fun RTS HybridAs hybrid RTS games are generally mediocre at best, I wasn't expecting much when I spent $2.50 on this few years' old game, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥- this is a lot of fun. There aren't many servers, but there really should be. I've got 1000+ hours into TF2 and I could see spending that much time in this Nuclear Dawn if it had a more active community. The replayability is huge, and with mods there's really no ceiling to how immersive this game could grow to be. Why? Because it appeals to a broader base and it's excitingly multi-dimensional. It's a great shooter, but if you aren't in the mood for gunfighting, you can command, and commanding people instead of sprites adds a whole different dimension. If you care about your soldiers as a commander, you can support one another's goals to huge success. Though I consider it an extremely desireable feature, the Achilles' Heel of this game is its dependence on leadership. Even more than the Battlefield series, not having a commander, or following an ineffective one, greatly undermines the team's chances to win. The soldiers rely on the commander providing upgrades, transport, and supplies they need to stay competitive.On the ground, gameplay feels a lot like Battlefield built over the Source engine, which is essentially what it is. Also a bonus, IMO. Squads, lots of adaptations to classes and unlocks, and pretty enjoyable from a lot of angles. If you're a purist in any one area, this may not be your bag. It's  not perfect at anything, but it's really good at almost everything. I'd love to see Nuclear Dawn make a comeback. I think this game really deserves a second look.

content:

												I got the game as a gift in the Steam Christmas Sale 2011 and played it for the first time about half a year later, because I really didn't know what I would get.Nuclear Dawn combines the elements of a squad-based shooter like Battlefield with the elements of an RTS: One player of each team becomes the commander, who can build defensive and offensive structures like turrets or power stations, while his teammates have to control ressource points and exterminate the opposing team.The mechanis work great if you are lucky to be in a good team - if not, you're doomed.The balancing on each map is outstanding and the leveling system with new perks is rewarding, but you have to put a lot of effort in it before it pays off; maybe a bit too much regarding the small rewards.But it's fun for a quick battle and the graphics look good, too.

There are no vehicles, this is because each team has a "Commander" who builds structures and researches upgrades for the team whilst playing the game Real Time Strategy style. Teamwork is absolutely required to win, which leads to genuine gratification. The maps are urban and very detailed, definitely some of the best and most memorable source maps I've ever seen. The game developers claim they are the biggest source maps ever. They did a great job on it and I not going to lie to you, this game makes my dong hard.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 15, 2011
												Being a solid PC multiplayer shooter that rewards good aiming and quick reaction (no cover system, no auto regeneration, fast kills)  it is a game about map control, ressource points and the clever use of those resourcepoints by the commander of the team. Dont expect a highly polished RTS part on the commanders side, though it is deep enough to promote strategical decisions.Depending on class, the pace is very fast (Stealth Class) to medium (Exo Class). Spawntimes are about 10sec and spawnpoints are dynamically build by the commander or destroyed by the enemy. Map design could be better, leaving you confused about blocked entries or dead areas, but overall it is getting the job done of creating main chokepoints and sideway entries where the balance of power can easily shift between the 2 teams, requiring each team to adapt to the new situation created by the enemy commander, like a newly placed missile turret or healing station.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Nuclear Dawn blends elements of FPS and RTS games in an interesting and unique way. The primary goal is to destroy the enemy's command bunker, where their commander sits and gives orders to his team and builds structures.In order to accomplish that goal, your team needs to capture resource points. There are three types of resource point: primary, secondary, and tertiary. There is only one primary (or "prime") resource point in a map, which is hotly contested by both teams. There are a few secondary points and many tertiary points. The bigger the point, the more resources it gathers for the team. Commanders use resources to unlock new technologies and to build new structures.Each team has a single commander, which is voted in. It's an interesting game, but it's a shame that so few people play it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Nuclear Dawn blends elements of FPS and RTS games in an interesting and unique way. The primary goal is to destroy the enemy's command bunker, where their commander sits and gives orders to his team and builds structures.In order to accomplish that goal, your team needs to capture resource points. There are three types of resource point: primary, secondary, and tertiary. There is only one primary (or "prime") resource point in a map, which is hotly contested by both teams. There are a few secondary points and many tertiary points. The bigger the point, the more resources it gathers for the team. Commanders use resources to unlock new technologies and to build new structures.Each team has a single commander, which is voted in. It's an interesting game, but it's a shame that so few people play it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												+ Fantastic contemporary & industrial aesthetics, with gritty, post-apocalyptic overtones and a dose of sci-fi. Settings are well-realised, with great overall detail - the game world in itself is a joy to experience.+ Exceptional urban level design (series like Call of Duty and Battlefield should take note)! Stages seem to have a geat variety of ranges, yet never feel TOO open or claustrophobic... the layouts are complex, but never overwhelming. Their large expanses and multi-building, multi-story designs give them a huge amount of variation, and they rarely feel repetitive.+ AI players are present, so the game is still fully playable when real players are absent.- There's basically NOBODY playing this game. Generally when I hop on, there's fewer than 10 people online across the game's many barren servers. It could be timezone issue, but it's an issue nontheless.- Bizarre acceleration on both mouse AND keyboard... both look and movement can be nauseating, and hard to control precisely.- The AI, whilst functional, is nowhere near on par an experience as the human vs. human interaction.- The UX could do with some work, as the game's interface is not simple to navigate.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												I purchased me and my brother this game and it happens to be one of the most interesting RTS\FPS's out there. This concept originally invented in the 1990's and rarely ever seen again is amongst one of the most exciting for those who want a fun shooter without having only objective points to worry about. The classes are well balanced with the assault class having the ability to decloak enemies, the stealth class is able to sneak around turrets and players assuming they have no radar, the engineer has the ability to destroy enemy structures fast, and oh yeah the exo, my favorite class, has the ability to shoot a high powered gatling gun with the ability to lock down and become a turret, or you can upgrade him and shoot magical fairy dust (guass cannon, dont think you werent thinking the same thing). That is just the tip of the iceburg as each class has customizeable features such as armor piercing and along with that comes  the ability to change to up to 2 other weapons sets. It's a great adaptation of a great gaming concept. being a rts fan this is quite simply the most enjoyable to play as. instead of AI or a group of units you get to kill the other team one by one personally and hear their rage from the other side of the room (as my brother always picks the opposite team). it's not grouped units, no. it's a whole server of enemy players coming at you battlefield 3 style and you get to stick a turret into their faces. Now of course they balance out he RTS and FPS by forcing you to wait for recources captured by the allies. Also once a commander you can easily leave that position and go fight yourself, or demote yourself and let someone else have a try. Overall this game makes you feeling good in the end because you cant camp with a m249 behind  a concrete wall. you have to actively dictate what you want to do and how you want to accomplish it. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME if you're going to sit around with a sniper rifle in a corner of the game. the levels are too well designed and too well thought out to let some jerk sit there and have his camping spree. but absolutely BUY THIS GAME if the standard point and click isn't doing enough for you and you want a real challenge.I'd buy this game again any day. and for the sale right now it was a no brainer. literally turned to my brother and said "will you play it? `cuz im buying it". Great game and great concept. addicting and exciting.PS imagineawesome is my brother. if you find him in game. kill him for me ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This is a unique blend of RTS and FPS action. Each team has one commander that plays the RTS role. They build turrets, extend their range, drop supplies, open up waypoints. All the fun stuff, but are still a FPS player sitting in a base. On the other side of things, as a player on the ground, you are in FPS mode as one of four classes, killing the enemy and taking over resources. The more resources you have, the more things your commander can build. It's like currency. They can't build if the FPS players can't get the points captured, but they need the help from the RTS guy, too. This game is amazing with some really unique playstyles. Each class has multiple roles it can play and different ways to ultilize them with different upgrade gizmos. If you're at all a fan of FPS or even RTS, give this game a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2012
												A year after release, and a near-dear community doesn't stop this ball from rolling. Nuclear Dawn is an FPS/RTS hybrid, akin to Natural Selection. The gameplay feels like Battlefield 2142 mixed with Command & Conquer. This is a game that is worth the cash, and unlike BF games, there's a lesser learning curve, as simple as playing the tutorials gets you the foundation of how to play this genius game. Running on the Source engine, it's also a spectacle. When you aren't looking at the brown that has preluded and infiltrated this game, you see some vivid graphics, curtousy of Interwave's incredible map designers. There's a way for everyone to play, and all you need to do is try it.This game may be empty, but Interwave is dedicated, and they plan a BIG patch for their anniversary. I recommend you buy it and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2011
												A very intense multiplayer experience. The game is currently in its "Vanilla" version and there is still some balancing/tweaking/polishing to be done. That doesn't mean, however, that this isn't a quality product. Far from it. First of all, it feels very "unique". I haven't played any other FPS/RTS hybrid in the past, i have tried however most multiplayer shooters that have come out in the last 4-5 years and this one feels much more intense. Even if you prefer a lone-wolf approach in multiplayer games this game will make you want to get involved with the team to hold out that capture point for 30s longer, to siege that turret and EMP their spawns, leaving you with an adrenaline rush and a great sense of satisfaction, knowing that you won that battle fighting tooth and nail against the opponent. Dev support is also a big plus for this one. All in all a VERY recommended purchase.

												WOW!  This is a LOT of fun!  I didn't expect it to be so awesome.  It plays a lot like that Half-Life mod "Natural Selection" - except the teams are balanced much more evenly.  It's all about how good your commander and players work together.  Assault is good at spotting Stealth.  Stealth is good at assassinating Exos.  Exos are good at killing Assault.  And then you have Engineers/Medics which play support roles, excellent at destroying/repairing structures, and keeping groups of players alive.

												It's an FPS, with some classes that resemble those from TF2, also, huge maps and mechanics that resemble those from Battlefield. 												This game is a hidden gem. It's probably one of the best strategy-shooters on the market. Playing as either the commander or a soldier feeds a strong sense of urgency and duty, and an adrenaline rush either way. There's nothing like trying to coordinate between com orders and where your dense allies are going. Seriously, it's a great game. Opening up achievements and perks over time that actually let you define your play (scope, silencer, specialized ammo, etc.) really gives you a sense of contributing. Mad props to people who play the /much needed/ medic or engineer.Favorite part: swearing at a commander who refuses to put down any supply stations. 10/10
