number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Come Back to this Really Fun RTS HybridAs hybrid RTS games are generally mediocre at best, I wasn't expecting much when I spent $2.50 on this few years' old game, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥- this is a lot of fun. There aren't many servers, but there really should be. I've got 1000+ hours into TF2 and I could see spending that much time in this Nuclear Dawn if it had a more active community. The replayability is huge, and with mods there's really no ceiling to how immersive this game could grow to be. Why? Because it appeals to a broader base and it's excitingly multi-dimensional. It's a great shooter, but if you aren't in the mood for gunfighting, you can command, and commanding people instead of sprites adds a whole different dimension. If you care about your soldiers as a commander, you can support one another's goals to huge success. Though I consider it an extremely desireable feature, the Achilles' Heel of this game is its dependence on leadership. Even more than the Battlefield series, not having a commander, or following an ineffective one, greatly undermines the team's chances to win. The soldiers rely on the commander providing upgrades, transport, and supplies they need to stay competitive.On the ground, gameplay feels a lot like Battlefield built over the Source engine, which is essentially what it is. Also a bonus, IMO. Squads, lots of adaptations to classes and unlocks, and pretty enjoyable from a lot of angles. If you're a purist in any one area, this may not be your bag. It's  not perfect at anything, but it's really good at almost everything. I'd love to see Nuclear Dawn make a comeback. I think this game really deserves a second look.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												A great combo of RTS and FPS, great community and a fun game which can add up to some massively cool battles. Maps are fairly large so there's quite a lot of variety, along with workshop support but I haven't played many community maps.Pros+Unique RTS, FPS combo+Can have pretty big and cool battles+Classes are fairly balanced, I haven't had a problem where one class surpasses the rest+Source engine is fab+Teamworky stuff+Community is nice+Normally decent commanders+I can imagine this game would be incredible with a bunch of palsCons-Very few used servers-Guns feel a little bit weak-Fairly dependent on having a decent commander, but this has never been much of an issue to me+-Games can be very long; can be seen as pro or con depending on the amount of time you haveA solid 8 flaming dinguses out of 10 from me,A must buy if you're looking for a bit of a change.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												An incredibly intriguing game. From someone that comes from Battlefield and loved being commander there, this just blows it all out of the water. This is top-nocht, high strategy, and incredibly fun. It takes all of what infantry combat should have been in a true battlefield game (no health regen, limited supplies, dependancy on a team, many different roles and classes, each unique and well distinguished) and perfects it. Too bad it has no vehicle warfare, but the variety of situations that will arise every game is just staggering otherwise. Excellent map design, with a lot of verticality involved. A small masterpiece

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												I feel like I've only scratched the surface of this one but the surface sure is fun.Had the pleasure of a few good games where teamwork really won the day, and when your commander has a headset, and uses it, oh boy! It's times like that that you wish more people played this game. It deserves a lot more credit than it has gotten. A bad rap I suppose from people who tried it and didn't quite give enough of themselves to it. You see this game isn't balanced in any particular way. If a tactic becomes dominant in a match then rather than whine to the developers to fix it (or nerf it) so you can play the way you want to, it's better in this game to figure out how to counter said tactic amongst the players on your team.For example an early rush of players as heavy building destroyers (called seige exo's) gunning straight for your base and ending the match in mere minutes can be avoided if there enough support players planting listening devices as early warning systems. It's possiblities like this, and the warm feeling you get when a plan comes together; whether you ordered it from the skies or executed it on the ground; that make this game one I hope to be playing for a good long while...... If only more people showed up to play ;-)

If a tactic becomes dominant in a match then rather than whine to the developers to fix it (or nerf it) so you can play the way you want to, it's better in this game to figure out how to counter said tactic amongst the players on your team.For example an early rush of players as heavy building destroyers (called seige exo's) gunning straight for your base and ending the match in mere minutes can be avoided if there enough support players planting listening devices as early warning systems. It's possiblities like this, and the warm feeling you get when a plan comes together; whether you ordered it from the skies or executed it on the ground; that make this game one I hope to be playing for a good long while...... If only more people showed up to play ;-)

Posted: April 4, 2016
												Nuclear Dawn would be a decent standalone FPS, and a decent standalone RTS. The combination of the two elements is brilliant. Ground combat in Nuclear dawn is difficult to compare to other FPS games, because the combat is more strategic than tactical. If you have a good commander in the bunker, it can be one of the best cooperative gaming experiences you can have. Nuclear Dawn has a really good community. Voice chat is functional, and rarely ever abused. Between the hybrid game mechanic and the quality multiplay experience, Nuclear Dawn is worth every penny.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2012
												The Good: Mixes RTS and FPS in a smart way, classes are fun to use, lots of people playing online, tug-of-war action during matches is addictiveThe Bad: No campaign, no bots, looks pretty average, ugly menus, 99% of the time you won't be playing the RTS part, a few balancing issuesMixing RTS (Real Time Strategy; Shogun 2, StarCraft) with FPS (First Person Shooter; Call of Duty, Quake) sounds like trying to hammer a nail with a banana, but it works here despite not seeing the RTS part too often. Unlike other games that poorly implemented RTS (Brutal Legend) into another genre, Nuclear Dawn does it right. The person doing the RTSing is the Commander and only he can do it. This is an online only game (boo!) so the Commander must be voted in, but usually that's the host and rarely will he ever get booted.The game uses standard RTS elements like building buildings that give your men on the ground more powerful ammo for their weapons (the FPS part is the men on the ground). You have to kill the Commander to win the game, but also capturing energy sources is also key for respawn points. Everyone knows an online FPS needs respawn points so that's the Commander's job by making sure there are plenty. The RTS elements are light and not very complicated, but you have the constant fear of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the guys down below and voting you off if you don't manage your resources right and build useful structures and give them frequent upgrades.As the guys on the ground you are doing all the work capturing resource points and killing that freaking Commander. You get to choose four different classes that have unique powers such as a tank that uses a minigun and can plant it and act like a human turret, or you can use alternate classes for each class like the tank using an energy type grenade launcher to knock out structures. You have a stealth class that can turn invisible for a while and knife people from behind. Plus you get the typical sniper and foot soldier roles that have various sub-classes. The shooting mechanics are simple if a little dated and the whole game is rough around the edges.Not that the isn't any fun because fragging with other players is loads of fun because this game has a back and forth kind of like Team Fortress 2 and a game can go on for over an hour. Once a team starting knocking out your resources you can make a come back and it's just like a tug-of-war. This can be loads of fun since you can switch classes after each death and use it to deal with a problem like people camping in a small room or snipers that no one can spot.Nuclear Dawn does not have a single player campaign or even offline bots so this is strictly online only. I really don't like that and it could use a campaign to get you better at playing it. Mainly because 99% of the time you won't be the Commander so you get almost no experience in the RTS part outside the tutorial. The menus are also pretty ugly and the whole game feels almost like a mod more than a full-fledged game, bu the unique mix of genres is worth a purchase for the low price anyways. The graphics aren't anything to write home about because they are pretty average and will run on any average computer. This game is strictly for hardcore online players only, but pick it up if you want something new.~Score: 8/10
